solution_line_template: A red ticket is equal to {blue_tickets_per_red_ticket} blue tickets, and a yellow is equal to ten red tickets, so a yellow ticket is also equal to {red_tickets_per_yellow_ticket} * {blue_tickets_per_red_ticket} = <<{red_tickets_per_yellow_ticket}*{blue_tickets_per_red_ticket}={blue_tickets_per_yellow_ticket}>>{blue_tickets_per_yellow_ticket} blue tickets.

It takes {yellow_tickets_for_bible} yellow tickets to win a Bible, or {yellow_tickets_for_bible} * {blue_tickets_per_yellow_ticket} = <<{yellow_tickets_for_bible}*{blue_tickets_per_yellow_ticket}={total_blue_tickets_needed}>>{total_blue_tickets_needed} blue tickets.

Tom has {tom_yellow_tickets} yellow tickets, which are worth {tom_yellow_tickets} * {blue_tickets_per_yellow_ticket} = <<{tom_yellow_tickets}*{blue_tickets_per_yellow_ticket}={tom_yellow_tickets_in_blue}>>{tom_yellow_tickets_in_blue} blue tickets.

He also has {tom_red_tickets} red tickets, which are worth {tom_red_tickets} * {blue_tickets_per_red_ticket} = <<{tom_red_tickets}*{blue_tickets_per_red_ticket}={tom_red_tickets_in_blue}>>{tom_red_tickets_in_blue} blue tickets.

Added with his {tom_blue_tickets} blue tickets, he has {tom_yellow_tickets_in_blue} + {tom_red_tickets_in_blue} + {tom_blue_tickets} = <<{tom_yellow_tickets_in_blue}+{tom_red_tickets_in_blue}+{tom_blue_tickets}={tom_total_blue_tickets}>>{tom_total_blue_tickets} blue tickets' worth of tickets.

So he still needs to earn {total_blue_tickets_needed} - {tom_total_blue_tickets} = <<{total_blue_tickets_needed}-{tom_total_blue_tickets}={blue_tickets_needed_more}>>{blue_tickets_needed_more} blue tickets.
